content: How can I help you today?

Well, my partner suggested I come see you because I’ve been having a really hard time sleeping. Work has been super stressful lately, and I just can’t seem to shut my brain off at night. I’m honestly not sure if talking about it will help, but here I am.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot right now between work stress and trouble sleeping. It’s understandable that you're feeling stuck when your mind won’t quiet down at night. Thanks for sharing this—it’s a big first step coming here. What do you feel has been the most challenging part of all this for you?

Honestly, the constant fear of losing my job is the hardest part. It feels like this weight that’s always hanging over me, and I can’t stop thinking about how I’d provide for my family if it happened. It’s just exhausting.

That sounds overwhelming—trying to juggle the fear of job security while also wanting to provide for your family. It makes sense that this worry feels exhausting and even weighs on you at night. What helps you manage or cope with this fear, even in small ways?

Honestly, I’m not sure I’m managing it at all. I just keep trying to push through the days, but by the time I’m lying in bed, all the what-if scenarios hit me at once. I guess I sometimes try distracting myself with my phone, but it doesn’t really help.

It sounds like you’re doing your best to push forward, even when the fears feel relentless. It's understandable you’d turn to your phone to try to escape the what-ifs, even if it doesn’t fully bring relief. How do you feel about exploring other ways to unwind or quiet those thoughts before bed?
I’m not sure—I’ve never really tried anything else. I guess I’m open to suggestions if you think it could help. It just feels like nothing’s going to stop these thoughts from rushing in.

Thank you for being open to exploring options, even when it feels like nothing will work. Those racing thoughts can feel very consuming, and it’s hard to imagine quieting them when they've been so persistent. Before jumping into any suggestions, would it help to look at some signals, like how you're sleeping or your activity levels, to see if they offer any insight? Or would you prefer to focus directly on these thoughts you're having?

Thank you for being open to exploring options, even when it feels like nothing will work. Those racing thoughts can feel very consuming, and it’s hard to imagine quieting them when they've been so persistent. Before jumping into any suggestions, would it help to talk more about what's happening at work that's been causing so much stress for you?
That’s a great idea—talking more about what’s been going on at work could help make sense of how this stress is impacting you. What’s been happening at work lately that feels most difficult for you?

I feel like I’m constantly falling behind. There’s so much pressure to meet deadlines, and I worry that my best isn’t good enough. I can’t shake the fear that my boss is disappointed in me, and with all the layoffs happening, I’m scared I’ll be next. It’s like the more I stress, the harder it gets to focus and do my job well, and then it just snowballs.

It sounds like there’s a lot of pressure on you, and it’s causing a cycle where the stress makes it harder to focus, and that adds to your worry about falling short. It’s tough feeling like your best might not be enough, especially during times of uncertainty with layoffs. What, if anything, has helped you feel supported or more grounded at work, even briefly?

To be honest, I haven’t felt very supported at work lately. It feels like everyone is just trying to survive, and there’s not much room to lean on others or ask for help. I don't really feel comfortable bringing up how overwhelmed I am with my boss either—they’re already under a lot of pressure too. It kind of feels like I'm on my own.

That sense of isolation at work sounds really difficult, especially when everyone around you seems stretched thin and you don’t feel comfortable sharing with your boss. It’s hard to carry all of that without feeling supported. Given how much you’re carrying, what do you think might help you feel less alone or overwhelmed—whether at work or outside of it?

I’m not really sure what would help. I guess maybe if I could just find a way to actually relax at the end of the day or get some of this off my chest without feeling like I’m just complaining. It’s just tough to even find the time or the energy.

It makes sense you'd feel unsure about what might help when you're already stretched so thin. Wanting a way to relax and share what's on your mind feels like an important step—it’s not complaining, it’s processing. Finding time and energy can definitely feel like another layer of challenge. What do you think could make it easier to carve out even a small moment for yourself after a long day?

Take your time—there’s no rush. If it helps, you could start by sharing what you normally do after work or before bed. Sometimes even small routines can offer ideas for what might bring ease or help you unwind. What does a typical evening look like for you?

Take your time—there’s no rush. If it helps, you could start by sharing what you normally do after work or before bed. Sometimes even small routines can offer ideas for what might bring ease or help you unwind. What does a typical evening look like for you?

Thank you for opening up even more about your evenings and what’s weighing on you. You mentioned turning to your phone as a way to try to distract from the stressful thoughts but not finding much relief, and you also brought up a desire to relax and let go of some of this weight. Is there anything else you’ve tried, or do you feel like relaxing feels out of reach right now?
